settings.title: How to Install Redwood Entrance Gates: A Step-by-Step Guide
settings.text: Entrance gates serve as a welcoming statement, enhancing the beauty, security, and value of your property. Installing redwood entrance gates may feel like a challenge, but with proper preparation and guidance, it’s a rewarding project that combines functionality and aesthetics. This guide will take you through each step, from choosing the right gate to adding those all-important finishing touches.

settings.title: Preparation: Setting the Foundation for Success
settings.text:
Step 1: Choosing the Right Gate

The first step is selecting a gate that complements your property and meets your practical needs. Are you opting for a single gate or a double gate? Consider the style, size, and material. Scandinavian Redwood gates from Ruby UK are a popular choice, offering natural beauty, durability, and resistance to the elements.

Our redwood gates are crafted from Joinery Grade Scandinavian Redwood, enhanced with tanalith pressure treatment. This treatment ensures long-lasting protection against rot, insect damage, and UV exposure, making them ideal for outdoor use.

Accurate measurements of your gate opening are critical. Measure the width and height to ensure a perfect fit and to avoid complications during installation.

Step 2: Gathering Tools and Materials

Having the right tools and materials on hand will make the installation process smoother. Here’s a checklist to get you started:

  • Spirit level
  • Tape measure
  • Post hole digger
  • Spanners
  • Drill
  • Concrete mix
  • Safety gear (gloves, goggles)

Step 3: Surface prep

Mark out the gate installation area and ensure the ground is level. If the ground is uneven, use a rake or shovel to level it out. Precise markings help ensure your gate is straight and symmetrical once installed.

Step 4: Install the Gate Posts

Dig Post Holes

  • Use a post hole digger to create holes that are one-third the height of your gate posts.
  • This depth ensures the posts can support the weight of the gate and withstand adverse weather conditions.

Set the Posts

  • Mix and pour concrete into the holes, then position the posts.
  • Use a spirit level to ensure the posts are perfectly vertical.
  • Brace the posts with timber supports to hold them steady while the concrete cures.
  • Allow the concrete to cure for at least 24 hours before proceeding.

Step 5: Hang the Gate

With the posts secure, it’s time to hang the gate. Precision is key to ensure the gate operates smoothly.

Attach Hinges

  • Lay the gate flat and position the hinges, ensuring they are spaced evenly from the top and bottom edges.
  • Mark the drill points on the gate and drill pilot holes to prevent splitting.
  • Secure the hinges to the gate with screws.

Secure the Gate to the Posts

  • With the help of a second person or props, lift the gate into position against the posts.
  • Align the hinges with the post and mark the drill points.
  • Drill pilot holes into the post and secure the hinges with screws or bolts.

Align and Balance

  • Use a spirit level to check that the gate is level when closed.
  • If adjustments are needed, loosen the hinge screws, reposition the gate, and retighten.
  • Test the gate by opening and closing it to ensure smooth operation without dragging or sticking.

Step 6: Add Finishing Touches

Now it’s time to finalize your gate installation with added functionality and protection.

Install Latches and Locks

  • Choose a latch or lock that meets your security needs, such as drop latches, bolt locks, or keyed locks.
  • Align the latch with the gate and post, mark the drill points, and secure it with screws.
  • Test the latch by opening and closing the gate to ensure smooth operation.

Apply Protective Coatings

  • Use a wood preservative, stain, or paint to protect your redwood gate from weathering.
  • Focus on exposed edges, as they are most vulnerable to damage.
  • Apply two coats for added protection, allowing the first coat to dry completely before applying the second.

Step 7: Maintain Your Gate

To keep your gate in excellent condition, perform regular maintenance:

  • Realignment: If the gate becomes misaligned, check the stability of the posts and adjust the hinges.
  • Prevent Sagging: Install a diagonal brace or anti-sag kit to reinforce the structure.
  • Lubricate Hardware: Clean and lubricate hinges and latches regularly to prevent rust and ensure smooth operation.

Step 6: Finishing Touches

Cut the boards to fit neatly around windows, doors, and other openings. Add trims or corner mouldings for a polished, professional finish.

Step 7: Protect Your Timber

To maintain your cladding’s beauty and durability, apply a protective finish such as oil, stain, or paint. This will help preserve the timber’s colour, prevent cracking, and guard against weathering.

Conclusion

By following these seven steps, you can confidently install your redwood entrance gate, adding both charm and security to your property. Whether you’re aiming for improved curb appeal or enhanced functionality, a properly installed gate is a lasting investment.
